text: [Music]
hi this is Brian with Amazon Web
Services and in this video I'm gonna
walk you through AWS session manager a
component of AWS Systems Manager a tool
for managing servers at scale what
session manager allows us to do is
remote in and manage our servers all
without running RDP or SSH let me show
you what it looks like first then we'll
go into some more details ok so the
first thing we're gonna do is let's go
into the AWS console and we'll click on
services and bring up Systems Manager
now once Systems Manager is up we're
going to scroll down we're going to
click on session manager so session
manager we want to look at preferences
first and in here let's edit this so we
can show the whole preferences Rennie's
an s3 bucket of logs and then session
manager is our folder that I've got
inside that log file next we're going to
look at cloud watch logs and choose the
SSM log file that i've created there
next let's go start a session so I'll
choose a Linux instance first here and
we'll start a session it brings up
another browser window where I've got a
full bash shell interface to run
commands and here we exited Who am I we
see that that's SSM user next I want to
do a disk listing to show the size of
the disk in the free space next let's
look at the IP addresses then I have
config and next let's look at all the
processes so we can do anything from
here we're full admin let's switch over
let's bring up a Windows session so
we'll start a session again and in this
case I'm gonna pick a Windows instance
instead as we start this session what
will happen is we'll get another browser
window brought up we have a session in
with PowerShell and run Who am I and we
see SSM - user again
I can do the exact same types of
commands I can get disk to see and what
disks are available it's a 30 gig disk
okay
who wants some free space I could do a
get PS Drive to get free space or run
other scripts that can get that I can
also list the network's stack here with
IP config and I can get other things
such as all the processes running and so
I've gotten the same information on both
things when I'm admin or root on both
now let's go take a look at I've got
both sessions running I can see that
they're both up and running right now
next we look at history and if I look at
history I can click on the s3 bucket
information and so this is what that
bring looks like I bring up my bucket I
download the file and I open this file
and we can see the transcript of the
entire session so we see not only the
commands I entered but the responses to
those commands we can get that same
information let's go back and let's look
at the cloud watch logs so I can get
complete information about everything
that's done which is something we don't
get when we let regular let RDP or SSH
in so here we've got the s3 bucket which
you looked at already let's click on
cloud watch logs and go look at the
cloud watch logs for that same
information so we click on that cloud
watch and all of this information will
list exactly like it was in the previous
log file now we don't have to use both
log class we can use one or the other
but that's what we have with session
manager
[Music]
okay so what I just showed you was
promoting into a Linux box with a bash
shell prompt and remoting into the
Windows machine with a PowerShell prompt
to do management of those servers
session manager raises a security bar in
a few areas the first area is that
there's no ports open
for hackers to hack at and try to log in
the second area is that it uses role
based access control to give access for
people to remote in and in the third
area it logs everything that we've done
and so it raises the bar of security as
well as gives us a great way to easily
log in to our servers and manage them
so that's AWS session manager thanks for
watching
[Music]
